messageBody:
For me there are some areas where testing tools could do more.

The first area is the integration in the IDE. I would like to have
quickly an overview of the test of the selected object.
For example in eclipse, we can have an overview of a class that we are
using. We should have similar shortcut to view the tests (maybe with
some descriptions?)


A second area concerns the creation of test values. In some domain,
it is not unusual to have functions taking very 'long' value object as
input. Some might argue that it should be avoided, but it is not
always possible. A good example where that can't be avoided is the
test of business rules in the insurance domain. An insurance contract
contains really a lot of data, and the business rules often use
totally unrelated part of the contract.
For such a case, I would like to have a very simple editor to easily
edit the test value and store them into a file. I think that some
adapted "bean editors" could do that, but I don't know if anybody has
already experiment this aproach.


Finally, my last "dream" is probably much less clear than the two
previous points, and certainly more complex.
I would like to see TDD colaborates with design by contract to give an
intermediate aproach taking the best of the two world.
I would like to be able to define somehow the contract of an
interface, and I would like to have this contract validated when I run
the test, and that even when I stub or mock the object. I'm convinced
that would allow to write more powerful tests that would be less brillant.
And ho, I forgot! My dream is to see that in java. :-)


Regards,
Gilles
